text:
NARRATOR: At present,
man is the master.
Metal is his slave.

But new discoveries on Earth and
on a dangerously close planet

nearby suggest that
we could face a threat
from monsters made of metal--

naturally evolving machine
like entities, creatures

who don't just tear
up our assumptions

about the very
nature of life itself

but who could
challenge and defeat
us for control of our planet.

We often assume that aliens
would be interested in us.

But these might just be
interested in our planet's
hot core.

NARRATOR: January
2018, Great Britain.

A scientist builds a machine
with almost godlike powers.
It is designed to create life--
but not as we know it.

This machine we built to
explore the origin of life

and to make
artificial life forms.

NARRATOR: By making
inorganic cells,

the machine brings together
different chemical compounds.

We put them onto the
surface of the planet,

if you like, and let them
interact with one another.

Then we're looking for droplets
that literally burst into life.

Within a few seconds,
they'll start

doing really strange
things as they explore
more of their environment.

So you got this one start
bursting around spontaneously.

NARRATOR: The cells in the
dishes act like they're living.
But it's not life as we know it.

LEE CRONIN: These
are completely dead.

We're just looking at
how inorganic cells can

take on lifelike
properties and fool
us into thinking it's alive.

And then at some point,
we're going to be able to not
tell the difference.
And then maybe it is alive.

NARRATOR: Cronin's life-making
machine is programmed

to automatically alter and
adapt its chemical recipes,

carrying out a kind of
unnatural selection--

evolution of a new form of
life in a lab at high speed.

I basically think we now know
how to make life in the lab.

Within the next
decade, we will have

made some very
odd-looking lifeforms.

NARRATOR: The life forms
Cronin is working on
are like nothing found on Earth.

LEE CRONIN: In my
lab, we've been

trying to make primitive life
forms based on an iron oxide.

Could life exist based
on metal instead of carbon?

If we manage to
make life in the lab,

that will allow us to
change our entire set

of parameters of how we would
look for life in the universe.

NARRATOR: Bizarre as it seems,
Cronin's and other experiments

are not only persuading
scientists that inorganic life
is possible.

They are already speculating
what that life might look like

and where in the universe we
might find it already existing.

Their research has led them to
look again at a nearby star.
55 Cancri is a sun-like star.

It's just a little bit smaller
and a little bit less massive
than our sun.

It's a star that is
only 40 light-years away,

which is basically the
equivalent of being
in our astronomical backyard.

NARRATOR: Around
this nearby sun,

they discover an exoplanet
of a type astronomers
call a super-Earth.

There's this planet
called Janssen.

And it's about twice
the diameter of Earth

and about eight
times as massive.

It's like Earth
but on steroids.

NARRATOR: Janssen is half the
size of the gas giant Neptune.

But it is made
out of solid rock.

And like our own
planet, this super-Earth
may well harbor life.

Super-Earths are good
candidates finding life,

because they're going to
have a lot of interesting
elements on them--

a lot of heat and
gravity to drag

these materials together
so the processes that
give rise to biology can start.

NARRATOR: For life forms
made from rock or metal

to evolve, geological, chemical,
and climatic conditions
would have to be just right.

Astronomers have
used Hubble Space

Telescope to look at Janssen
and look at its atmosphere.

It seems like Janssen
does have an atmosphere.

And it actually might
be kind of thick.

And it might be
kind of Earth-like,

with a lot of nitrogen
and some oxygen
and maybe even some water.

NARRATOR: Like Earth, but in one
important way very different.

If you were standing on the
surface of planet Janssen,

the sun in the sky would
appear 60 times bigger.

And it would be 3,600 times
brighter than our sun.
Janssen is very, very hot.

It's something like
4,000 degrees Fahrenheit.

That is just far and beyond
anything we can even imagine.

NARRATOR: For humans,
this super-Earth
is a vision of fiery damnation.

You would see liquid metal
precipitating like rain
out of the atmosphere.

You would be buffeted by
incredibly high-speed winds
coming from every direction.

It would be like visiting
Dante's version of hell.

The conditions on Janssen
mean instant death

for anything that we would
understand currently as life.

STEPHEN GRANADE:
Life on Earth is

centered on DNA,
on proteins being
arranged in different orders.
And it's all kind of delicate.

If you put too much heat into
it, those chains of proteins

fall apart, and life
becomes next to impossible.

NARRATOR: The intense
heat is enough to turn
solids into fluids--

hell for organic life, but
an atmosphere and climate

necessary for the evolution
of inorganic beings.

This planet has oceans,
but they're oceans of lava.

On a planet like
Janssen, you'll have
molten lakes of metal, of rock.

Would they act sort of
analogous to an ocean on Earth
that creatures could live in?

If you move away from carbon
and carbon-based molecules,

you can ask, could
you create life
out of inorganic chemistry?

NARRATOR: We know of the
potential for inorganic life
from laboratory tests.

But such a different
form of life

would break all the rules
of biology as we know them.

How would such creatures
look or think or behave,
even on a chemical level?

That's one of
the amazing things

about the prospects of finding
life on foreign worlds--

is that the chemistry
that's available
we can't even imagine.

Liquid metal creatures
sounds extreme.

But we've actually
started building

the first initial blocks
of them here on Earth.

Imagine what a lab the size of
a planet given billions of years
could accomplish.

NARRATOR: Sci-fi
writers have already

imagined such fluid
metal monsters
in the "Terminator" movies.

Because of the nature of
the place that they live,

it would be almost impossible
for any component to them
to be solid.

It would be very difficult
to imagine them having
anything resembling a skeleton.

So if anything, they'd be
more like amorphous blobs,
perhaps like the T-1000.

NARRATOR: Liquid metal organisms
living in the fiery lakes

of Janssen, growing red
hot and able to shape shift
into any form they want.

STEPHEN GRANADE: Do you
take a more spherical shape

to conserve energy, to have as
little surface area compared
to your internals as possible?

Do you take a more elongated
shape for predatory activities?

NARRATOR: Such liquid
metal beings would have
evolved as we have evolved--

to adapt and to survive
the conditions around them.

The idea that they move around
by manipulating magnetic fields

within their own body
would potentially

mean they could do so with
objects around them as well.

NARRATOR: Is it impossible
that after billions of years

on this fiery
super-Earth evolution

will have produced creatures
as advanced or more advanced
than on our own cold wet Earth?

I think, if they're
good at working metal,

they would be able
to potentially make

metal structures in
ways that we're not as
used to and not as skilled at.

They'd be used to working with
things in their molten state

and would have had
to have developed
the techniques for doing so.

They would be taking advantage
of the tremendous amount

of energy pouring
in from their star.

NARRATOR: Having mastered the
elements on their home world,

would they then look, as we
do, to venture into space?

The beings on Janssen, if
these metallic liquid T-1000s

do exist down there,
would look at Earth
and see an absolute hellscape.
They would all freeze to death.

NARRATOR: But if the
Janssenites can travel

through the bone-chilling
vacuum of space to get here,

then they will have the
technology to overcome anything
the Earth can throw at them.

Their spaceships
will obviously

emulate the environment
on their planets.

They would have to keep those
temperatures and the pressures

sufficient to keep
themselves together

and to keep themselves
from solidifying.

What's more, there
are places on the Earth

where the liquid
metal Janssenites
might feel almost at home.

If they were looking
at visiting Earth,

volcanoes might be a
reasonable place to go.

NARRATOR: It is no doubt a
coincidence that many reports

of unexplained aerial
phenomenon happen

close to volcanoes, whose
temperatures can reach
to 2,200 degrees Fahrenheit.

There's some reporting of UFO
reports in different volcanoes
throughout the world.

Are they visitors from Janssen
or a similar type planet?

They'd have to go fairly deep
into our mantle before they got

to a spot where they
would consider it
to be real beach-like for them.

NARRATOR: Earth's
molten outer core,

1,800 miles inside the
planet, has temperatures

of 4,000 degrees Fahrenheit,
the same as Janssen's
scorching hot surface.

The liquid metal aliens could
be swimming in the molten ocean

beneath our feet right
now, unbeknownst to us.

I would imagine, if
these aliens turned up,
it would be entirely bizarre.

Would we tell the difference
between an inorganic form

visiting and a meteorite
going through the Earth's
atmosphere really hot?
I don't know.

NARRATOR: Just as we
might not recognize them,

they might not even
see us as life forms--

just strange clumps
of organic matter

scattered over the thin
crust of our planet.

I find it very
difficult to believe

that we could interact with
them in any meaningful way.

NARRATOR: If they decided to
wipe their new world clean,

we may not have any way
of asking them to stop.

[CHAOTIC MUSIC AND SOUND
 EFFECTS]
